author: By Roger Cohen
title: At Funeral for Nahel M. Near Paris, Anguish, Anger and Racial Tensions
description: For many in the crowd, including hundreds who could not fit in the mosque to mourn the teenager killed by a police officer, his story felt familiar.
content: PARIS — For two hours, in a mood of anguish and anger, hundreds of members of the large French Muslim community lined up outside the Ibn Badis mosque in Nanterre to mourn a teenager, one of their own, fatally shot by a police officer at a traffic stop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Ryan Mac
title: Musk Says Twitter Is Limiting Number of Posts Users Can Read
description: The change on Saturday came as thousands of users complained about getting an error message that they had “exceeded” their “rate limit.”
content: Elon Musk said on Saturday that Twitter will temporarily limit the number of posts users can read per day to address concerns over data scraping, just hours after thousands of users reported widespread problems using the site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Hollywood Actors Extend Contract Talks at Deadline
description: Their union, SAG-AFTRA, and the major studios pushed the expiration date ahead to July 12 and will keep negotiating.
content: The union representing some 160,000 television and movie actors said on Friday night that it would continue contract negotiations with the major Hollywood studios and streaming services, extending the current deal — which had been set to expire at midnight — through July 12.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Beating Heat Wave Is Even Harder With Drums
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 2, 2023.
content: “I’m on the sidelines dripping from every crevice. And they don’t even look grumpy about it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Lepore
title: How to Stave Off Constitutional Extinction
description: The best way to save it is to amend it.
content: Every Fourth of July, Americans celebrate independence, but it might be more significant, more pregnant with meaning, to celebrate amendment — the writing, ratifying and especially the amending of constitutions. Except lately there hasn’t been much to celebrate, with amendment having become a lost art. And a constitution that can no longer be amended is dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Maggie Haberman
title: DeSantis, Seeking Attention, Uses L.G.B.T.Q. Issues to Attack Trump
description: The Florida governor sought to contrast his record opposing gay and transgender rights in a video highlighting comments made by the former president during the 2016 campaign — but has gotten some pushback.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis’s campaign shared a provocative video on Friday attacking the record of former President Donald J. Trump regarding L.G.B.T.Q. people that was widely condemned as homophobic, including by a prominent group representing gay and lesbian Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Ruined Town, Resolved to Stay ’Until the End’
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 1, 2023.
content: “People used to live here, but they left. Today, I’m the only inhabitant of the street.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Supreme Court Decisions on Education Could Offer Democrats an Opening
description: The decisions this week on affirmative action and student loans give Democrats a way to make a case on class and appeal to voters who have drifted away from the party.
content: Ever since President Bill Clinton advised “mend it, don’t end it,” affirmative action has had an uneasy place in the Democratic coalition, as omnipresent as the party’s allegiance to abortion rights and its promises to expand financial aid for higher education — but unpopular with much of the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Dutch King Apologizes for His Country’s Role in the Slave Trade
description: The Netherlands formally abolished slavery in its colonies in 1863, but has only recently begun to actively acknowledge its participation in the practice.
content: King Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands formally apologized on Saturday for his country’s role in the slave trade, a rare direct apology for a historical injustice by a sitting European monarch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
title: Are Escalators and Moving Walkways Safe?
description: A woman in Thailand lost part of her leg after it was caught in an airport walkway this week. The accident has gotten a lot of attention, but such injuries are extremely rare.
content: An airline passenger in Thailand had part of her leg amputated this week after an accident on a moving airport walkway, the Thai authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Certain Surprise Party?
description: Ben Tolkin makes a hip debut.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I have a soft spot for constructors who debut with themeless puzzles, and there is a lot to love about this grid by Ben Tolkin. The stair-stepped entries at its top and bottom all crackle, and most of them are debuts, as well; there’s excellent wordplay throughout, and a lot of trivia for lovers of language and literature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Elise Young
title: Gov. Murphy Looks to Burnish Legacy With a $54.3 Billion Budget
description: New Jersey’s election-year spending plan is 7 percent higher than last year’s.
content: Philip D. Murphy, a wealthy former Goldman Sachs executive who had never held elected office, took over as governor of New Jersey in 2018 as an unabashed liberal Democrat and in his first term enacted a millionaires tax, a $15 minimum wage and mandatory paid time off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Aurelien Breeden
title: Macron Cancels State Visit to Germany Amid Unrest at Home
description: More than 1,300 people were arrested overnight as riotous protests again gripped France over the police killing of a 17-year-old and the country’s president stayed home to deal with the crisis.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France on Saturday postponed a scheduled state visit to Germany as his government struggled to rein in violent protests over the deadly police shooting of a 17-year-old this past week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: 2 Leading Theories of Consciousness Square Off
description: Scientists revealed the results of experiments testing how our brains give rise to conscious thought — and ended a 25-year-old bet.
content: On a muggy June night in Greenwich Village, more than 800 neuroscientists, philosophers and curious members of the public packed into an auditorium. They came for the first results of an ambitious investigation into a profound question: What is consciousness?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, June 24-30
description: Cornered, many players had to face the music with “plena.”
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fabien Cousteau
title: I Know What Drives People to the Depths of the Ocean
description: Fabien Cousteau on the draw and importance of ocean exploration.
content: On my fourth birthday, my father found me at the bottom of the pool, sharing air supply, or “buddy breathing,” with a family friend; I was having my first scuba experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: At the Front Lines of the Inflation Fight, Uncertainty Reigns
description: Central bankers and economists gathered this week and, amid concerns about persistent inflation, wondered about all the things they still don’t know.
content: When prices started to take off in multiple countries around the world about two years ago, the word most often associated with inflation was “transitory.”  Today, the word is “persistence.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler, Kurtis Lee and Jill Cowan
title: From the Docks to Dodger Stadium, Los Angeles Workers Are Feeling Emboldened
description: California union members are pressuring employers over wages in one of the nation’s most labor-friendly states.
content: In the two months since they went on strike, screenwriters have become a fixture outside studios in Southern California, signs aloft as the traffic roars past. In many parts of America, theirs would be a lonely vigil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Austin
title: A Mother Reckons With Questions From Her Childhood
description: Beth Nguyen left Vietnam and her biological mother when she was a baby. Her memoir “Owner of a Lonely Heart” examines the ripple effect of those departures.
content: Some of the most poignant scenes in Beth Nguyen’s new memoir, “Owner of a Lonely Heart,” take place at night. Waking from restless dreams to scribble a sentence, checking in on her children in their beds, working at her desk after sunset, Nguyen is forever “writing in and into the darkness.” Awake at 3 in the morning, she nurses her newborn, counts the other lit-up windows and ponders questions familiar to all new parents: What was it like for my mom? Did she feel what I feel?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allegra Goodman
title: A Fractured Family Heads North
description: Remember the people who fled to second homes during the pandemic? Caitlin Shetterly wrote a novel about them.
content: Wherever you go, there you are. The adage rings true in Caitlin Shetterly’s tender debut, “Pete and Alice in Maine.” During the first weeks of the pandemic, Pete and Alice flee New York City for Maine with their young daughters, Sophie and Iris. Life in the city seems impossible during lockdown, but Pete and Alice are also dealing with a crisis of their own. Driving up to Maine, they carry with them confusion, grief, anger, guilt, longing — all the emotions of their troubled marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Michael J. de la Merced
title: Fireworks Have a New Competitor: Drones
description: The light displays are quieter, safer and better for the environment.
content: Like many in the fireworks industry, Stephen Vitale is in the family business. He runs a fifth-generation company, Pyrotecnico, in New Castle, Pa. In October, he struck a surprising alliance with Nova Sky Stories, the drone company that Kimbal Musk acquired from Intel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Luke Broadwater and Michael S. Schmidt
title: U.S. Attorney in Hunter Biden Case Defends Investigation to House Republicans
description: David C. Weiss, a Trump appointee, denied that he had retaliated against an I.R.S. official who testified about divisions in the case.
content: The U.S. attorney in Delaware denied retaliating against an I.R.S. official who had disclosed details of the Hunter Biden investigation, and denied being blocked from pursuing serious charges against Mr. Biden, the president’s son, in Los Angeles and Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Tang
title: The Supreme Court Has Opened the Door to Discrimination. Here’s How States Can Slam It Shut.
description: The court’s rulings are not the final chapter. The people often retain powerful ways to protect themselves through common-sense lawmaking.
content: The Supreme Court has sided with a Christian graphic designer who refuses to create wedding websites for gay or lesbian couples. The result comes as little surprise. Writing for a six-justice conservative majority, Neil Gorsuch said that Colorado’s anti-discrimination law violates the designer’s right to free speech because the state “seeks to force an individual to speak in ways that align with its views but defy her conscience about a matter of major significance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Long Live the King!
description: In an age of division, there’s something to be said for royals as a unifying symbol — plus, they are good for tourism and gossip.
content: LONDON — With the thrill of coronation still in the air outside Buckingham Palace, it’s tempting for a Yankee to mock the British for the shop windows full of coronation plates and King Charles III coffee mugs. And how can we not roll our eyes when a slice of cake from the 2005 wedding between the new king and queen now sells for $1,600?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: Does It Help to Know How Much the Boss Makes?
description: Sky-high C.E.O. pay isn’t a secret. And transparency about those big numbers can have surprising effects on the work force as a whole.
content: In 1933, the U.S. government asked 2,000 corporations listed on stock exchanges in New York to disclose how much they paid their top bosses — its first effort at making the pay of executives more visible. The idea was to encourage the “more conservative management of industry,” The New York Times reported when it published some of the results on its front page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne
title: Mutiny Provided Glimpse of a Post-Putin Russia. Is the Window Still Open?
description: Yevgeny Prigozhin’s revolt showed the possibility of a Russia after Vladimir Putin — and how pro-democracy forces may not be the ones that take over.
content: For a millisecond, it seemed possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: An Indigenous Leader Who Raised Corruption Allegations Is Ousted
description: The Assembly of First Nations removed RoseAnne Archibald as its national chief this week after a harassment investigation
content: Happy Canada Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger
title: American Cities Have a Conversion Problem, and It’s Not Just Offices
description: Piles of regulations, or “kludge,” and a culture of “no” are limiting the ability to turn building blocks into something new.
content: There is an aging office building on Water Street in Lower Manhattan where it would make all the sense in the world to create apartments. The 31-story building, once the headquarters of A.I.G., has windows all around and a shape suited to extra corner units. In a city with too little housing, it could hold 800 to 900 apartments. Right across the street, one office not so different from this one has already been turned into housing, and another is on the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Hunter Biden’s Daughter and a Tale of Two Families
description: The story surrounding the president’s grandchild in Arkansas, who has not yet met her father or her grandfather, is about money, corrosive politics and what it means to have the Biden birthright.
content: There is a 4-year-old girl in rural Arkansas who is learning to ride a camouflage-patterned four-wheeler alongside her cousins. Some days, she wears a bow in her hair, and on other days, she threads her long blond ponytail through the back of a baseball cap. When she is old enough, she will learn to hunt, just like her mother did when she was young.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Mike Isaac
title: A ‘Cage Match’ Between Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg May Be No Joke
description: Talks over a matchup between the two tech billionaires have progressed and the parameters of an event are taking shape.
content: The day after Elon Musk challenged Mark Zuckerberg on social media to “a cage match” last month, Dana White, president of the Ultimate Fighting Championship, received a text.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Piepenbring
title: You May Not Have Asked; He Answered Anyway
description: Dan Schreiber’s “The Theory of Everything Else” is a return to the golden age of the trivia compendium.
content: There was a time when library shelves fairly sagged with strange reference works. Readers could peruse “The Best,” a 1974 hit that cataloged all things superlative, including bedsheets, sunscreens and life insurance policies. They could plunge into the RAND Corporation’s “A Million Random Digits with 100,000 Normal Deviates,” something of a bible among data scientists. Or they could cozy up with “The Dictionary of Imaginary Places,” containing entries on El Dorado and Jurassic Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Before Wimbledon, There’s Practice on Grass at an English Garden Party
description: The Boodles, which draws elite players on their way to the All England Club, is unlike nearly anything else on the tennis calendar — a Gatsby-like few days on an estate outside London.
content: Even for the best tennis players in the world, the days before a Grand Slam can be filled with nerves and stress, especially the time leading up to Wimbledon, the grandest Grand Slam of them all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson and Olivia Wang
title: Wagner Uprising Highlights China’s Risks With Russia
description: Xi Jinping needs Vladimir Putin to remain in power, and Russia to maintain stability, to help uphold the countries’ shared interests and to keep challenging the United States.
content: Just three months ago, China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, was in Moscow clinking glasses with Vladimir V. Putin and expressing his confidence in the “firm support” the Russian president enjoyed among his people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Biden Rules Tighten Limits on Drone Strikes
description: The New York Times obtained a declassified version of rules for drone strikes and commando raids, along with a counterterrorism strategy document, via a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit.
content: U.S. military and C.I.A. drone operators generally must obtain advance permission from President Biden to target a suspected militant outside a conventional war zone, and they must have “near certainty” at the moment of any strike that civilians will not be injured, newly declassified rules show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Why Platonic Friendships Are So Hard to Keep
description: On the show ‘Platonic’ and what research says about old straight married people and opposite-sex friends.
content: The show “Platonic” is about a pair of old friends, Sylvia and Will, who reconnect after years on the outs. Sylvia (Rose Byrne) is a stay-at-home mom of three kids, Will (Seth Rogen) is recently divorced and child free. In the first episode of the Apple TV+ series, we learn that their close friendship had broken up in part because Will’s ex-wife didn’t get along with Sylvia. Sylvia reaches out when she discovers they are no longer together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar and Emmanuel Morgan
title: The N.F.L.’s Betting Penalties Put Ideal of ‘Integrity’ to the Test
description: The penalties have been harsh for players caught breaking the N.F.L.’s gambling rules. That’s partly because the league wants no insinuation that games might be rigged.
content: When the N.F.L. on Thursday announced that three players had been found to have bet on football, the penalties came down with characteristic harshness: indefinite suspensions that can only be appealed after a full season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harrison Stetler
title: France Is on Fire
description: The country is in the midst of a revolt over police violence and racism.
content: PARIS — “I’m a fully-grown adult, but my mother still seems nervous whenever I leave the house,” Djigui, one of the thousands of protesters who took to the streets on Thursday afternoon in Nanterre, a working-class suburb of Paris, told me. “I can hear the crack in her voice when she checks to make sure I have my ID card or just says, ‘Watch out.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Elena Kagan Has Had Enough
description: Her dissent on the student loan decision is revealing.
content: You have probably already heard about the Supreme Court’s decision in Biden v. Nebraska, where a 6-to-3 majority of the court — split along partisan lines — struck down President Biden’s student debt relief plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh and Troy Closson
title: The ‘Unseen’ Students in the Affirmative Action Debate
description: Race-conscious admissions helped only a tiny fraction of Black and Hispanic students. It could not address the many obstacles to a college degree.
content: For as long as she remembers, Dolly Ramos hoped to have “the college experience,” she said, and one day become a nurse. But her biggest obstacle wasn’t competing for a spot at the school of her choice — it was attending and affording college at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Governor Vetoes Louisiana’s Ban on Transition Care for Transgender Minors
description: Gov. John Bel Edwards, a Democrat, also vetoed two other recent bills related to gender expression and sexual orientation in schools and among young people.
content: Gov. John Bel Edwards of Louisiana vetoed a ban on gender-transition care for transgender minors on Friday, standing in the way of his state becoming the latest to prohibit that kind of care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: My Building Manager Wants to Get on My Renter’s Insurance. Is That Legal?
description: It depends on what kind of apartment you rent. And it may actually be a good idea.
content: Q: I have lived in my New York rental apartment for over six years, having signed three previous two-year leases. Each lease has requested proof of renter’s insurance. With the current lease, the building management is requesting that I name them as an additional insured party. It seems as though they’re trying to pass on their insurance costs to me. Is that legal?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: Boy George Loves His Deeply Flawed Heroes
description: The Culture Club leader on the complicated artists that shape his worldview, and the grand hats that help him make a statement.
content: Boy George was chatting with Leonardo DiCaprio, an acquaintance from years ago, at a Cannes party in May when he realized the actor wasn’t particularly interested in their reunion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 1, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 1, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about a hearing regarding the derailment of a freight train in Ohio incorrectly rendered some information as a direct quotation. Robert Wood, Norfolk Southern’s director of hazardous materials, did not say at a hearing, “Eventually, if we did nothing, the cars were going to go through a violent explosion.” That was an element of a question he was asked regarding what he had told the fire chief in East Palestine, Ohio. The article also misquoted Mr. Wood. He said, “We believed that our only alternative left was probably going to be a vent and burn,” not “We believed our only alternative left was a vent and burn.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: John Roberts, Conservative Statesman
description: The chief justice behaves like a kind of G.O.P. president we haven’t had.
content: The unusual powers of the American Supreme Court have unusual effects on all its members, but especially on whichever justices hold the balance of power: Their role fits especially uneasily with the letter of the Constitution and modern democratic norms, evoking more ancient forms or concepts — the Roman censor, the Greek archon, Plato’s philosopher-king.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple and Jonah M. Kessel
title: A Salute to the Honest(ish) Russian Warlord
description: Now that Yevgeny Prigozhin has left the battlefield, who will tell Russians the truth?
content: The Opinion Video above is about Yevgeny Prigozhin, the Russian warlord who led a short-lived rebellion in Russia last week. The mutiny stunned the world, but it was a rebellion foretold. For months, Mr. Prigozhin, who commanded a totally ruthless mercenary force and is himself a product of the Russian kleptocracy, had been an unrestrained critic of the Russian military command, unleashing raw and candid critiques via his Telegram account. For reasons that are still not entirely clear, Russia’s leader, President Vladimir Putin, had allowed Mr. Prigozhin to hammer away at the Kremlin, which is particularly astonishing given how many of the government’s critics have wound up either imprisoned or dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chantel Tattoli
title: The Art of Drinking? Right This Way, S’il Vous Plaît.
description: Anya Firestone leads what she calls “cou-tours” around Paris: Tours tailored to the clients’ interests, be they dinosaurs, drag queens or booze.
content: On a recent morning at the Louvre, Anya Firestone handed out bottles of Evian. “Because ‘the art of drinking’ begins with hydration,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Robert Kennedy Jr. Reports Income of $7.8 Million
description: The presidential candidate and anti-vaccine activist made nearly $1.6 million from consulting work for a law firm known for litigation against pharmaceutical companies, a filing showed.
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the political scion and prominent vaccine skeptic who is challenging President Biden for the Democratic presidential nomination, reported an income of $7.8 million in the year leading up to his entry into the race, including nearly $1.6 million from his consulting work for a personal injury law firm known for litigation against pharmaceutical companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Bryan Tarnowski
title: An Early Heat Wave Upsets the Rhythm of Life in the South
description: Outdoor workers, fishermen and a group of students who waited all year for an intensive band camp are all searching for ways to adapt to the pervasive heat.
content: The drum line stood beneath a canopy of trees and rattled through rolls of sextuplets, with reddened shoulders glistening. As the sun blistered the parking lot, rows of trumpet, tuba and mellophone players marched back and forth, wiping sweat from their foreheads at the end of each passage of music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz
title: When Is a Cannibal Not a Cannibal?
description: Most of the time, reports of our ancient human ancestors eating one another turn out to be greatly exaggerated.
content: Everybody’s quick to see a cannibal. The Romans thought the ancient Britons feasted on human flesh, and the British thought the same about the Irish. Not a few prehistoric finds have been attributed, evocatively if not accurately, to the work of ancient cannibals. In 1871, Mark Twain commented on the discovery of the bones of a primeval man who purportedly had been made a meal of by his peers: “I ask the candid reader, Does not this look like taking advantage of a gentleman who has been dead two million years?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: TikTok Sells A Lot of Books. Now, Its Owner Wants to Publish Them, Too.
description: As ByteDance launches a publishing company, many in the book world wonder if it will create an uneven playing field by boosting its own authors at the expense of others.
content: A new publishing company began courting self-published romance writers earlier this year. The pitch, delivered in a generic email, was impersonal and formulaic. The terms weren’t generous, sometimes amounting to just a few thousand dollars for the rights to a book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: The Mystery That Ended Two Women’s World Cup Dreams
description: An assault case that rattled one of France’s best soccer teams remains unresolved despite a series of arrests. Its main characters have paid a heavy price.
content: Aminata Diallo was being escorted from her foul-smelling holding cell to an interview room inside the Hôtel de Police in Versailles the first time she heard the name Tonya Harding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Sheriff Recorded Making Inflammatory Comments Won’t Face Charges
description: Oklahoma’s attorney general said he had found no evidence to charge the sheriff, who was caught on a recording as county officials discussed killing journalists and Black people.
content: Oklahoma’s attorney general said on Friday that a sheriff who was caught on a recording as other county officials discussed killing journalists and Black people would not face criminal charges but suggested that the governor endorse another candidate in the next election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Botswana and De Beers Sign Deal to Continue Rich Diamond Partnership
description: Under the new joint mining agreement, Botswana will immediately get a 30 percent share of the rough stones extracted, up from 25 percent, and it will rise to 50 percent within a decade, De Beers and government officials said.
content: A Botswana government official and the chief executive of De Beers, the international diamond conglomerate, signed interim agreements on Saturday to continue a lucrative, decades-long diamond mining partnership that had appeared to be breaking down in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: In the Paris Suburb Where Police Shot a Teenager, Violence and Vigilance
description: French suburbs have been rocked by riots that have tapped into a deep-seated resentment toward the police. Many residents understand the anger, but not the violence.
content: The first detonations of fireworks echoed through the neighborhood after a long, tense wait. A group of masked young people on scooters sped up a street lined with charred cars, heading toward the noise and billows of black smoke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: Paper Magazine, the Oral History: ‘They Were Wide Open’
description: It started as a chronicler of all things downtown. After success came, it morphed into something else. Now Paper has a new owner — and an uncertain future.
content: Paper Magazine made its debut in June 1984. The first issue was a foldout poster with a look as minimalist as the publication’s name, matching the raw aesthetic that reigned over Lower Manhattan in those days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Why Bolsonaro Was Barred in Brazil but Trump Can Run in the U.S.
description: In both the United States and Brazil, former presidents made baseless claims of fraud, and their supporters stormed government buildings.
content: Down in the polls, the far-right president warned of voter fraud, despite no evidence. After losing, he claimed the vote was rigged. Thousands of his supporters — draped in the national flag and misled by conspiracy theories — then stormed Congress in a bid to overturn the results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: On ‘The Bear,’ Interning at a Fine-Dining Restaurant Is Rosier Than Reality
description: Real-life chefs said the portrayal of haute cuisine work was a bit soft-focus.
content: In its second season, the hit FX show “The Bear” ventures into the world of fine dining. As the scrappy Chicago restaurant crashes toward a reopening, two of the employees leave to apprentice at top restaurants in Chicago and Copenhagen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Darren Drozdov, a Former Pro Wrestler, Dies at 54
description: A former N.F.L. football player known as Droz and Puke, he had his pro wrestling career cut short by an injury in the ring in 1999 that left him quadriplegic.
content: Darren Drozdov, a former N.F.L. football player who pursued a career in pro wrestling that was cut short after an accident in the ring that paralyzed him, died on Friday. He was 54.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Where Reparations Stand in the U.S.
description: Despite pockets of momentum in various cities, the fight for reparations is an uphill struggle.
content: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Jersey Boy Takes On Florida Man
description: With his old pal Trump, Christie goes from enabler to destroyer.
content: I offered to help prep Chris Christie for the debate with Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: Where to Watch July 4 Fireworks in the New York City Area
description: Macy’s world-famous show, Coney Island’s display and alternative celebrations in Staten Island and New Jersey: here’s where to enjoy a show this year.
content: Numerous firework displays are scheduled to light up the skies in and around New York City this Independence Day, including the 47th annual Macy’s Fourth of July celebration, which will send 60,000 shells into the night sky from five barges in the East River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: To Foreign Policy Veteran, the Real Danger Is at Home
description: Richard N. Haass says the most serious threat to global security is the United States.
content: Everywhere he has gone as president of the Council on Foreign Relations, Richard N. Haass has been asked the same question: What keeps him up at night? He has had no shortage of options over the years — Russia, China, Iran, North Korea, climate change, international terrorism, food insecurity, the global pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Karam Shoumali
title: Everyone Knew the Migrant Ship Was Doomed. No One Helped.
description: Satellite imagery, sealed court documents and interviews with survivors suggest that hundreds of deaths were preventable.
content: From air and by sea, using radar, telephone and radio, officials watched and listened for 13 hours as the migrant ship Adriana lost power, then drifted aimlessly off the coast of Greece in a slowly unfolding humanitarian disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadie Stein
title: Child’s Play
description: An editor recommends old and new books.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernhard Warner
title: How Amazon Taught Alexa to Speak in an Irish Brogue
description: For Alexa to speak like a Dubliner, Amazon researchers had to crack a problem that’s vexed data scientists for years: voice disentanglement.
content: Like Henry Higgins, the phonetician from George Bernard Shaw’s play “Pygmalion,” Marius Cotescu and Georgi Tinchev recently demonstrated how their student was trying to overcome pronunciation difficulties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joel Fagliano
title: A Mini Challenge
description: A special edition of a Times puzzle designed for Morning readers.
content: Because I’m the creator of the New York Times Mini Crossword, people often assume that I’m a trivia expert. The embarrassing truth is that my trivia knowledge is heavily weighted toward things with four and five letters and a lot of vowels. Sure, I can tell you Elvis Presley’s middle name (Aron), or that a small sewing kit is known as an “etui,” but I’m not going to be much help at your local pub trivia night.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Breakthroughs in Cancer Research and Treatment
description: Readers respond to Kate Pickert’s essay about the recent revolution in tackling cancer.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: A Small Town’s Fourth of July: Flags, a 5K and Trump’s Attacks on American Institutions
description: Ahead of a holiday meant to celebrate the country’s history, the former president tore into American institutions and attacked his political opponents.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump drew a crowd of thousands on Saturday to a quiet South Carolina town’s Independence Day event, where he assailed the integrity of major American institutions and painted a dark portrait of the country ahead of a holiday meant to celebrate its underpinnings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Alicia Parlapiano
title: Along With Conservative Triumphs, Signs of New Caution at Supreme Court
description: Chief Justice Roberts delivered both landmark victories for the right and significant rulings in which he forged alliances with the liberal justices.
content: The Supreme Court ended its term this week in familiar fashion, issuing blockbuster conservative decisions on affirmative action, gay rights and student loans that divided along partisan lines, with the court’s three Democratic appointees in dissent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: The Dark Universe Is Waiting. What Will the Euclid Telescope Reveal?
description: The European Space Agency mission, which launched on Saturday, will capture billions of galaxies to create a cosmic map spanning space and time.
content: At 11:12 a.m. on Saturday, the Euclid spacecraft launched into space on its mission to chart the history of our universe as far back as 10 billion years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennie Coughlin
title: These Runners Confront Challenges Together
description: Both volunteer guides and runners with disabilities find community and support on the run through Achilles International.
content: About nine months after Mauricio Blandino suffered a traumatic brain injury in 2011, he was still working on being able to walk without assistance, and his outlook on life was in decline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Ukraine Says It Is Ready for Arrival of Wagner Troops in Belarus
description: Ukrainian officials have tried to tamp down concerns while heralding their preparations, with President Volodymyr Zelensky nodding to plans for reinforcing the border.
content: As Belarus has ratcheted up its messaging about plans to offer refuge — and possibly work — to Wagner group mercenaries after a failed rebellion in Russia, Ukrainian forces say they are ready for any potential threat from their neighbor to the north.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: About Two Feet
description: Rebecca Goldstein and Rafael Musa step it up with an arch Sunday crossword collaboration.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian and John Ismay
title: Coast Guard Apologizes for Covering Up Long History of Sexual Assault
description: The U.S. Coast Guard acknowledged it had failed for almost two decades to properly investigate sexual assault allegations at the service’s academy or hold perpetrators accountable.
content: The U.S. Coast Guard apologized on Friday for covering up scores of documented sexual assault and harassment cases that took place at the service’s academy, and failing to properly investigate or discipline those accused in dozens more cases over a span of nearly two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: 9 Ways to Stay Shaded on a Sweltering Day in New York City
description: The city is preparing for extreme heat by introducing new methods to keep out of the sun and expanding on those more tried and true.
content: With above-average temperatures predicted for this summer, New Yorkers are bracing for a scorcher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: In the Conference Realignment Game, a Deadline Is Not a Deadline
description: San Diego State had to make a decision about whether to leave the Mountain West Conference. It stayed put, but a move to the Pac-12 still beckons.
content: The latest turn of the college football-driven conference realignment carousel took me back to the Pleistocene Era of journalism, when I worked as a summer news desk clerk amid the telex machines, pneumatic tubes and desk drawers full of booze at the dearly departed Los Angeles Herald Examiner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple and Jonah M. Kessel
title: A Salute to the Honest(ish) Russian Warlord
description: Now that Yevgeny Prigozhin has left the battlefield, who will tell Russians the truth?
content: Now that Yevgeny Prigozhin has left the battlefield, who will tell Russians the truth?
source.name: The New York Times
